text: <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3417/> very easy one to save a lot of debugging printouts on the screen
<@U1HFNJB50>: Can you please update the commit message according to the update that Binhn asked?
<@U11MANG9G>: since default configured to INFO current messages reflects Binh comment as well
Also not sure such tiny thing worth CI round
CI is pretty jobless these days

In general, it is easier (for me) to work with a protocol. That is, just like the non-author sign-off, for example to “verify that a commit message reflects the change set, etc.”

In this case, it’s relatively “academic”, as I have already approved it the second I learned that the commit message accurately describes the CR, but in general, I just find it easier to work with a “general” deterministic guideline. Even though in some cases, it requires an extra CI cycle or two…. hope you’d appreciate that on average, it makes sense.

:christmas_tree: Gossip Multi-channel support is my present for Hyperledger fabric members for Christmas :christmas_tree: 
Here is the first chain of commits that adds multi-channel support for gossip. We still don't support multi-channel support across organizations because we need additional functionalities that need to be implemented in the peer,  and other reasons I can expand in PMs, but inside the org- it is implemented. The following is the chain of commits (to make the review less intimidating) 
<https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3515/> --> <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3525/>
Edit: 1 down, 2 to go (thanks <@U0KM61BCP> & <@U0ULK2JPP> )
